creditline: Gift of Louis W. Hill, Jr.
inscription:
英国の空地烏徳（うゑちうヽと）は幼き時
疾を得て不具と成しが其
国の陶器の粗なるを憂ひ
数年工夫して精巧の品を
造り出し国の大益を成せり
或人之を誉て此人この疾ある
に心を内に用ひて此術を
得たるなりといへり

{Eikoku no Wedgewood wa, osanaki toki yamai wo ete fugu to marishi ga, sono kuni no tōki no so naru wo urei, sūnen kufū shite, seikō no shina wo tsukuri dashi, kuni no taieki wo naseri. Aru hito kore wo tatae te kono hito sono yamai aru yue ni kokoro wo uchi ni mochii geijutsu wo e zaru nari to ie ri.}

(The British man Mr. Wedgewood lost his leg from his childhood disease. When he was grown up, he noticed that most British pots were poorly made. He was determined to create pottery of good quality in Britain. After long and hard work, he finally established his own way to make them. The Wedgewood pottery brought a huge wealth to Britain. It is believed that his disability made him a great art creator.)
medium: Woodblock print (nishiki-e); ink and color on paper
portfolio: From Lives of Great People of the Occident (Taisei ijin den 泰西偉人伝)
title: Josiah Wedgewood
